newsitem.title: UK: TABLE TENNIS-SAMSONOV UPSETS KONG, MEETS WALDNER FOR TITLE.
newsitem.headline: TABLE TENNIS-SAMSONOV UPSETS KONG, MEETS WALDNER FOR TITLE.

text.p: Fast-rising Belorussian Vladimir Samsonov zeroed in on his first world table tennis title on Sunday by upsetting world number one and title-holder Kong Linghui to reach the final.

The lanky 21-year-old from Minsk inflicted a 21-15 21-18 17-21 21-17 defeat on the Chinese player, who also holds the Olympic crown, to earn a title tilt on Monday against former champion Jan-Ove Waldner of Sweden.

Waldner, 10 years older than his opponent, defeated Yan Sen of China 21-17 21-14 21-12 to move within a match of adding a second world title to the one he captured in 1989. He also lost the 1987 and 1991 world finals.
Samsonov, who lives and trains in Duesseldorf, will go into battle with the memory of a 21-6 21-7 victory over Waldner in the team event last week.
"I think he didn't sleep very well before that day because it was too easy. This will be much tougher, six and seven against Waldner, this is not known," Samsonov said.
Samsonov was as proud to win for Europe as he was to score his fourth victory over a Chinese player in the event.
"Last time China won everything and I thought that could happen again but now we have an all-European final. This is important for the game," he said.

Kong, tired after a five-set quarter-final victory over compatriot Ma Wenge earlier in the day along with three doubles matches, could not stay with the 1.89-metre tall Samsonov in the first two games.

He bounced back to take the third, winning two of the best points of the match from 19-17 to force a fourth game. It was close all the way but Samsonov won five points on his own serve to move from 11-9 down to 14-11 ahead.
Kong got within a point at 17-16 but two forehand errors, a forehand winner from Samsonov and a backhand out of court by Kong ended it.
"I played so many matches I was very, very tired. I couldn't concentrate," Kong said.
"This was our fourth meeting and I won the other three but they were all very close."
In the earlier quarter-finals, Kong outlasted Ma 16-21 22-20 14-21 21-15 21-12 while Samsonov shredded the tough defence of Ding Song of China and won easily 21-13 21-9 21-10.

Waldner scored a 21-17 21-14 21-12 victory over 1993 world champion Jean-Philippe Gatien of France in the quarters and after beating Yan was asked how well he was playing and how long he could continue.
"The game is developing every year and as I'm getting older I must be getting better," he said. "When I cannot win the big tournaments, then I will stop."
In the women's final, world and Olympic champion Deng Yaping, 24, defeated compatriot Li Ju 21-12 21-19 21-7 21-12 and will face another Chinese in the final.
Her opponent will be 19-year-old Wang Nan, who subdued team mate Wu Na 29-31 21-10 21-16 21-15.
"There is nothing special about her game except her experience," Wang said of her final opponent Deng.
